poem:
### Conversion

In dust-heavy aisles, I wandered,  
Unaware of a voice in the wood.  
Pages whispered, but Dylan,  
Oh, how his silence roared.  
  
A name once distant, now  
Strikes the chord in my marrow.  
Amidst mumbled echoes, a call  
Clear: in the whorl of words  
He matters, as all unloved  
Icons eventually do.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Don’t look back: after decades of apathy, A Complete Unknown has turned me into a Dylan nut | Laura Snapes The bookshop in the town where I used to live had a world-beating second-hand selection. The music section alone was so bounteous that there was a second shelf dedicated solely to books about Bob Dylan. One of them provided an inadvertent punchline to the six-foot display, proclaiming: Why Dylan Matters. Thank god, someone said it!". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Don’t look back: after decades of apathy, A Complete Unknown has turned me into a Dylan nut | Laura Snapes The bookshop in the town where I used to live had a world-beating second-hand selection. The music section alone was so bounteous that there was a second shelf dedicated solely to books about Bob Dylan. One of them provided an inadvertent punchline to the six-foot display, proclaiming: Why Dylan Matters. Thank god, someone said it!
